channel.title: One valid argument against Open Source
channel.description:
An email I received this morning, the other email has been censored.
[u][b]Need your concact email[/b][/u] 7 messages ******* ****** <*********@yahoo.com> Sun, Mar 4, 2012 at 11:05 AM Hi please give ur email to me i Need to talk about ur Tetris game source [hr] moparisthebest Sun, Mar 4, 2012 at 11:15 AM This is it. What do you need ? [hr] ******* ****** <*********@yahoo.com> Sun, Mar 4, 2012 at 11:19 AM So i can add it in my MSN? I need to talk to u about Tetris code [hr] moparisthebest Sun, Mar 4, 2012 at 11:20 AM I don't use MSN or any other chatting software, just ask me over email. [hr] ******* ****** <*********@yahoo.com> Sun, Mar 4, 2012 at 11:24 AM Its hard to explain But I'll try it .. Well I needed a Tetris project by OpenGL and ur Source code was very nice but the only thing i needed and that doesn't exist in yours is the 3D thing, my teacher wanted me to give those objects a little 3D view.. Hope i could explain it ,, can u help me ? [hr] ******* ****** <*********@yahoo.com> Sun, Mar 4, 2012 at 11:35 AM What happened :(? Please help me . answer pls [hr] moparisthebest Sun, Mar 4, 2012 at 1:42 PM I'm sorry, but my days of doing homework are over, good luck.
Also a valid argument against chat software like MSN. ;D

item.title: One valid argument against Open Source
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:20, topic:435132”][quote author=Phillipé link=topic=537851.msg3935752#msg3935752 date=1331040375]

shame it wasnt from his .edu so youcould forward it to his lecturer

Do you think that chap honestly has a .edu email?
[/quote]
who the fuck does have a .edu email, mines .ac.uk[/quote]
My email address ends with .edu.au, and we keep them after graduation. I think it’s important to have the edu at the end, especially when you want to use the email address for professional correspondence and future employment opportunities.

Read full topic

item.source: One valid argument against Open Source

item.title: One valid argument against Open Source
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

yakman:

But Linux, Apache, Firefox, Wikipedia and thousands of other open source projects are providing examples where people work for reasons other than personal profit. They are proving people like SETO wrong.

Yes and no. Firefox is developed by a company that brings in $100million+ a year, though it is of course a non profit. Wikipedia and Apache likewise. But to downplay the involvement of massive corporations and pretend open source is some communist utopia is disingenuous imo. Most of the big heavy lifting comes from profit motivation just like anything else.

Read full topic
item.source: One valid argument against Open Source

item.title: One valid argument against Open Source
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

veer:

Out of curiosity, Moparisthebest… being a minarcho-capitalist, how do you reconcile your beliefs with the FOSS ideals? They seem very Proudhon mutualist to me.

Capitalists like SETO are right to be afraid of open source. Inherent in the open source philosophy is work not based on profit, and there being no private property of software.

Let’s look at some definitions for a second.
Capitalism - private ownership of the means of production
Socialist - collective ownership of the means of production
Communism - the abolishment of private property

Free open source is about software not having a single owner, but being free to use/modify/share by everybody. If you look at the above definitions of different political-economic systems, you’ll notice open source effectively comes under the last two systems, not the first one.

FOSS people constantly fight against patents and DRM, after all what are those thing if not companies trying to make private the communal software that we collectively worked on?

every program is [b]threatened constantly by software patents[/b]. States should not allow [b]patents to restrict[/b] development and use of software on general-purpose computers, but in those that do, we wish to avoid the [b]special danger that patents applied to a free program could make it effectively proprietary[/b]. To prevent this, the GPL assures that patents cannot be used to render the program non-free.

If you look at the things SETO says against open source, they are the same stuff said for anarchism, socialism and communism.
“It won’t work because there’s no incentive”

But Linux, Apache, Firefox, Wikipedia and thousands of other open source projects are providing examples where people work for reasons other than personal profit. They are proving people like SETO wrong.

There’s a reason the GPL is described as a copyleft license, because the ideas that underpin it are straight from the political left wing.

Read full topic
item.source: One valid argument against Open Source

item.title: One valid argument against Open Source
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

I’m of the opinion it doesn’t even matter whether open source directly brings in revenue or not. It’s the concept of cooperative development of ideas which makes open source so awesome. Whether companies are ought to do open source or not, their employees most likely will participate in the open source movement directly or indirectly at some point in their careers, just as a scientist that’s working for the public sector or event a lot of private sector organizations will have a tendency to openly publish their findings for all to see.

Read full topic
item.source: One valid argument against Open Source

item.description:

Oh, and I guess google makes no money from its open-source android, right SETO? Which is also based on Linux, incidentally.

item.title: One valid argument against Open Source
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I don’t think he’s trolling, I do however think he’s just guessing and has no real idea how the Open Source world works.

Red Hat did $909m revenue in 2011 - they’re not some Mom and Pop store.

Read full topic
item.source: One valid argument against Open Source

item.title: One valid argument against Open Source
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

SETO:

in the assumption everything is open source…i still don’t get how would corporation could make money (well not much), when a developed idea can be accessed and sold my anyone.

By offering service that others don’t offer. Look at Linux. It’s open source, but there are company’s that sell distro’s.

Science is pretty much open source, yet most applications of scientific research are not things you can make at home. You still need company’s, yet there aren’t monopolies because the science behind a product is available to everyone.

Read full topic
item.source: One valid argument against Open Source

you can say that all you like, but it would be a better idea to look at what actually happens. plenty of money goes into open R&D.

yes, but where did that money came from?
[/quote]Corporations…[/quote]
in the assumption everything is open source…i still don’t get how would corporation could make money (well not much), when a developed idea can be accessed and sold my anyone.

[quote=“Greeny, post:25, topic:435132”]I’m just going to assume SETO is trolling till he can cite anything that backs up these silly claims.

imagine if the who world was open source, 99% of the innovations and finding would not exists

This is hilarious.[/quote]

in the sense that vital technology (what we wanted will exists), because the funding will come from the government to do that so

item.title: One valid argument against Open Source
item.dc:creator: @SETO SETO
item.description:
@SETO wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:19, topic:435132”][quote author=SETO link=topic=537851.msg3934445#msg3934445 date=1330956042]
open source == no innovation, nor any improvement in modern technology.

We advanced in technology this much, not because of open source, but by not having it!
[/quote]

clearly absurd - tons of innovation comes from open source. bitcoin? ksplice? anything done in a university CS dept. in the past 10 years?[/quote]
honestly that what this generation thinks. imagine if the who world was open source, 99% of the innovations and finding would not exists. small example, if its open source most thing will be developed from grant from the government (who is gona pay for it? expect the public, because whats the point of investors investing money on it when anyone can use it for free) and why would the public was to pay for such things as, hair loss medicine, Viagra, etc…when the money could be spent on technology and drugs that could save peoples lives…

Read full topic
